title: Mum left shocked after being shamed by four-year-old daughter’s nursery for putting cake in her lunch box
text:
Mrs Crunch 'Cake is a sometimes food' Mum left shocked after being shamed by four-year-old daughter’s nursery for putting cake in her lunch box 
Australian Jessica Gianoni was given a 'condescending' note about the cake - despite also including a sandwich, fruit and rice crackers By JOSIE GRIFFITHS Click to share on Facebook (Opens in new window) Comments A MUM was left reeling when a teacher sent a “condescending” note to shame her for including a slice of cake in her daughter’s lunch box. 
Australian Jessica Gianoni gave four-year-old Isabel the sweet treat as part of her lunch, and the nursery teachers were not happy about her decision. 2 Jessica Gianoni’s daughter Isabel was given this letter to take home to mum 
However, instead of speaking to Jessica, from Adelaide, in person – it was left to Isabel to tell her mum about the note, which was left in her otherwise empty lunch box. 
According to Jessica, Isabel said: “You’re in trouble, mum”, when she returned home – while the cake was confiscated, and replaced with a “healthy alternative”. 
The note read: “WHOOPS! Sorry, cake is a sometimes food. “Today your child was packed a ‘sometimes’ food in their lunch box that doesn’t align with our Healthy Eating Policy. 
“They were offered a healthy alternative instead (smiley face). 
“If you need suggestions for healthy food alternatives please feel free to speak to the Kindy (kindergarten) Staff.” 
Speaking to Adelaide Now , Jessica said the note was “very condescending”, adding: “As a parent, I should be able to choose what my child should have.” 
Jessica continued: “She had a container of fruit including a banana, a sandwich and rice crackers. It wasn’t like the cake was the only thing she had to eat. 
“Instead of putting the note in her lunch box, she (the teacher) could have spoken to me when I picked Isabel up.” FSU footballer Travis Rudolph has lunch with autistic kid so he doesn't eat alone Facebook 2 Another mum received this note after putting a slice of cake in her child's lunch box 
When contacted by Adelaide Now, teacher Bianca Clothier said the healthy eating policy was devised last year because staff noticed kids sometimes became naughty after eating sugary food. 
Bianca added that the “little reminder notes” used language consistent with how children were spoken to by staff. 
Jessica is far from the only Aussie mum to experience something similar. 
Earlier this month, a mum-of-eight was left shocked after a slice of chocolate cake , which she had baked herself, was the subject of a similar note. 
Her red note, which had a sad face at the top, read: “Your child has, ‘chocolate slice’, from the Red Food category today. Please choose healthier options for Kindy.” Smash your lunch with this amazingly easy burrito box recipe
